title: 108_hr3797
content: The Act titled "2004 District of Columbia Omnibus Authorization Act" requires the submission of a plan by the school board for the allocation of funds under the mayor's proposed budget. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to include a new subsection requiring the Board of Education to submit a plan for the allocation of the Mayor's proposed budget to the Council by March 1 each year. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to require the Board of Education to submit a detailed plan for allocating funds to each school, including specific descriptions of funds under the school's control and other funds benefiting the school. SEC. 3. Multiyear contracting authority and leasing agreements for District of Columbia courts. This section amends the District of Columbia Code to allow for multiyear contracting authority and leasing agreements for the courts in the District of Columbia. The Executive Officer has the authority to enter into contracts for severable services and leasing agreements for the District of Columbia courts. The contracts for services can span fiscal years, similar to executive agencies. The leasing agreements are for buildings accommodating the courts, with terms deemed beneficial for the Federal Government and the District of Columbia. The Executive Officer has the authority to enter into multiyear contracts for property or services for the District of Columbia courts, with terms beneficial for both the District of Columbia and the Federal Government. The Executive Officer can enter into multiyear contracts for property or services for the District of Columbia courts. Changes in terminology and funding amounts are specified, and procedures for cancellation or termination due to insufficient funding are outlined. The Executive Officer can enter into multiyear contracts for property or services for the District of Columbia courts, with specified changes in terminology and funding amounts. Appropriations currently available for procurement of services must be used, or funds appropriated for those payments. SEC. 4. Establishes the academic year as the fiscal year for District of Columbia schools. Section 441 of the District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to establish the fiscal year for the Armory Board starting on January 1st and ending on December 31st, and for District of Columbia Public Schools and University of the District of Columbia starting on July 1st and ending on June 30th of each calendar year. SEC. 5. The deadline for the Council to adopt the budget is extended to 56 calendar days to account for days of recess. SEC. 6. District government employees on compressed schedules are exempt from federal overtime requirements. District government employees on compressed schedules are exempt from federal overtime requirements. A compressed schedule is defined as an 80-hour biweekly work requirement scheduled for less than 10 workdays for full-time employees, and less than 80 hours for part-time employees. This exemption applies to hours worked after the enactment of this Act. Section 856(a) of the District of Columbia Government Comprehensive Merit Personnel Act of 1978 is amended to include enforced annual leave or enforced leave without pay for attorneys. The amendment will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, there is a provision for the regulation of District of Columbia banks by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act is amended to remove references to District banks in various sections. This includes changes in subsections related to State banks and the exclusion of District banks in certain provisions. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act is amended to remove references to District banks in various sections, including subsections related to State banks and exclusions of District banks in certain provisions. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act is amended to remove references to District banks in various sections, including subsections related to State banks and exclusions of District banks in certain provisions of other banking acts. The Protection Act of 1968, Depository Institution Management Interlocks Act, and Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are all amended to remove references to banks located in the District of Columbia. The Protection Act of 1968, Depository Institution Management Interlocks Act, and Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to remove references to banks in the District of Columbia, including changes to various sections of the laws. The National Bank Receivership Act is also amended by striking a specific section, and a sentence in the Federal Reserve Act is modified. The Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. 321) is amended to remove a specific provision. The effective date for these amendments is the enactment date of the Act. The Act and its amendments will be effective starting from fiscal year 2005 and onwards.
